content.rendered:
In honor of the projects we Salvaged during the 2013 Brand New Awards judging, here is a selection of three of them that I hadn’t seen before from Lima, Merida, and Zurich.

Cementos Inka by Brandlab

Available in Peru since 2002, Cementos Inka produces a small selection of cements for construction. Previously sold in a naive-looking bag with the help of a cartoon representation of an Inca, the cement now comes in a bad-ass bag, designed by Lima-based Brandlab, that (pun!) mixes a contemporary approach with a sprinkling of Incan visual motifs. It’s almost as if Vitesse was designed to be paired with pre-Hispanic patterns. See full project.

Sarur Arquitectura by BIENAL Comunicación

Founded in 2010 in Mexico City, Sarur Arquitectura is an architecture and interior design firm whose founder’s last name happens to have many of the same letters found in the Spanish word, Arquitectura. Merida, Mexico-based BIENAL Comunicación took advantage of that to create a shorthand for the company, SARQUITECTURA, underlining and rotating the “SARUR” in the name as a subtle, graphic secret. It’s a small twist that solves nicely the long name and provides some cleverness to the otherwise minimal identity. See bigger images (no project page).

enfant terrible, Bar & Café by Studio Eusebio

There is probably every reason to hate this but, still, I think it’s great and different and unique. enfant terrible, Bar & Café, in Zurich, Switzerland, is a restaurant with a musical bent, specifically jazz and hip-hop. Designed by local firm Studio Eusebio, the identity has many elements, starting with a super smart logo: an ampersand. Not impressed? Ampersands are originally the ligature of “et”, Latin for “and” — “et” are the initials of enfant terrible. Score! The octagon shape comes from the shape of the floorplan of the restaurant itself and its 45-degree angles inspired the choice of a weird, upright italic script font thing called Monocto. Then there is the halftone screen patterns which… I have no idea where they came from but they add to the overall oddity of the project. See full project.
